i mean... it depends? in general a piece of music becomes memorable through repetition and familiarity. so i’d change what you said to “isn’t the vast majority of music instantly forgetable”. 

even something on the top 40 probably won’t be memorable to someone who just hears it once (although a lot of pop music is created with so many hooks that are repeated over and over again partly so they will be instantly memorable). “back in the day” (we’re talking pre 1960s) showtunes and pop music had a ton of cross over with most of the hits being endlessly covered on the radio. composers would often, as well, do reprises of the songs they thought would become the biggest hits later in their shows, to increase their familiarity (andrew lloyd webber still basically does this—repeating constantly whatever melody he hopes will have a life outside of the show). of course simpler songs/melodies (as lopez’ stuff tends to be—and that’s not a knock at all, it’s a legit way to write) are also usually more quickly memorable.

the disney songs tend to be catchy, but they also are so memorable because most of us grew up with them *everywhere* stephen sondheim’s scores used to be criticized for not being memorable (he mentions out that one of his early shows had a song that suddenly people praised him for writing a memorable melody—he pointed out that that melody was repeated over 40 times in the show...) as a teen, that used to strike me as crazy talk because i would listen to the cast albums from his show dozens (or more) times and could basically hum to you any of the major songs or melodies.

i admit i’m not a big wicked fan but did see it once—but i definitely know popular and defying gravity enough to be memorable just because they pop up in so many places if you pay attention to theatre.

i think, and i am not one to draw up battle lines by any means, that there is probably a valid distinction (well, no, not a distinction, but certainly a spectrum) to be drawn between people who connect with doctor who for its uniqueness, and those who connected with doctor who for the way it in turn connects to the rest of the “cult entertainment” landscape. 

i certainly feel that the show was leading up to something rather more self-consciously “cult” than it ever was when i was a huge dorky fan: to me the show was always meant to be a mainstream, saturday teatime family affair, and to me the marvel of that was just how such a blummin’ weird and wonky show attained water-cooler status. i mean it’s hardly bloody dynasty is it, but for the better part of its life it was a show on everyone’s radar (this may be slightly less the case for american pals, but it had its own unique ephemeral status in the eyes of the mainstream there).

but i think to others, particularly new(er)comers, doctor who is more like the british version of american cult tv; kind of like star trek or the x-files with a bit more family banter and “englishness”. i can’t fault anyone for wanting that, or enjoying that, but i certainly get the feeling that the show panders and encourages that kind of reading (can’t blame the beeb really; they gotta make this show commercial where they can, given that they’re not allowed to advertise on it in the uk). it is what it is, but it’s a bit beyond the reasons i ever loved the show.

in any case, if you’re on my side of the fence welcome. sit on the porch, put a rug on your lap and help me bark “git offa mah lawn” to anybody who takes the twelve regenerations thing as gospel rather than an off-the-cuff plot device to make one particular mid-70s story work and which was never really meant to last.

i played alien isolation, and found it more frustrating than scary. with all the repetition the game requires, familiarity starts to set in quick, and that is the death of horror! having to repeat a sequence over and over again after getting caught by the xenomorph means you eventually figure out the patterns. you start seeing the algorithms controlling it, and learn to anticipate where it’s likely to pop up next. you never feel like you’re being stalked by a single deadly entity; you feel like you’re moving from one spawn point to the next, and ducking the critter until its algorithm tells it to stop looking for you and move on.

there are better health care systems that are way cheaper. there is a vast literature, tons of data and research on what works and what doesn’t and some of them are so basic, it’s mind-numbing. we know exactly what drives health care costs up and some of them are completely preventable/reversible without leading to any drop in quality. we know exactly what to do to reform the american system, which is exceptionally wasteful. there is no political will to do it. (now i wish i could say the same for education. that is an extremely complicated field, and no nation has a simple solution and pretty much all solutions involve spending more money. education needs more money to be better, health care doesn’t. some sort of mandatory universal health care insurance is a must (single-payer is the cheapest option, but it’s not necessary). pharmaceutical pricing is out of control in the us because the government (medicare) is banned from negotiating with pharma companies by the congress (what? yes, other countries negotiate prices like all companies do).  hospitals artificially inflate prices of everything to 10-100 times the actual cost (it’s an accounting trick that wrecks the whole system). all developed countries have some sort of universal insurance. these insurance companies negotiate prices. they do not allow advertising drugs (no advertising costs), and most developed countries do not allow artificially inflated prices -they are regulated. so for instance, if you get an ultrasound in europe, your insurance is charged 100 euros, but in the us it costs 3000 dollars. there are other, more controversial measures, but they are controversial. spending less on end-of-life care (old people vote and most of the health care spending goes to very old people who are in the last month of their lives) and spending more on prenatal care and children’s health is a big money saver. healthy babies become healthy adults. this is not done in the us because babies do not vote. spending more on preventive health care saves money, but it also extends lives, so it may cost us more in the end. it’s up for debate. prescribing less non-essential medicine is another method of decreasing addiction, and saving money. it’s also not a popular option in the us. but if you just reform the insurance system, hospital accounting systems, and regulate/negotiate drug prices, it will have no effect on the quality of the health care, but it will be way way way cheaper (like in europe).

it seems simply but there’s a ripple effect. a missed shoot day is a huge loss for the company as a whole. say you’re shooting at a location, and you’ve paid 10-50k for that location for the day. and you only have it for that day. and you miss that shoot day, well that generates paperwork. the locations team has to rebook/recontract it based on the schedules that the ad team has to redo and that filters down to production (every location is insured), accounting (redo payments), set dec (usually sets are dressed the day before, so set dec has to come and undress them and has to bring in people to redress if the day is rescheduled) etc. it’s not a small thing. productions are meticulously planned for a reason, every cog has a job.

with regards to this movie’s in-hindsight-weird cultural omnipresence in 1989, i think you have to seriously take your hat off to whatever set of geniuses put together the marketing campaign for it. the billboard ads for the movies were brilliant: just a simple close-up shot of the batman chest badge logo in front of a black background, with the date below it:

prince added many millions to the profits of the film. (it cost 35 million, and made 410 million.) before prince was attached, the project was a cult film - a mixture of burton fans and comic fans, nicholson was the only reason adult mainstream media took it seriously at all.  suddenly prince was attached to the project and it became a cross-media phenomenon: mtv, morning talk shows and chatter on the radio, not just movie ads and fast food commercials.  i still consider burton and prince to be an almost painful artistic partnership (prince’s style was entirely unlike burton’s, and burton had absolutely no clue what to do visually or editorially with prince’s music), but it was an outstanding piece of marketing for both sides of that matchup, and prince deserves more credit for the film’s ticket sales than he gets.

i was 16 when i saw this in 1989 and had a similar though also in many ways different reaction to this film and the huge pop cultural phenomenon it was. there are some good posts later about the power and ubiquity if this movie’s marketing campaign but i think they all point to a big part of why this movie was such an insane blockbuster: i have no idea if the numbers bear me out on this but it seemed to have a marketing and advertising campaign that was bigger than what had been done for any previous film. so, by the time opening weekend rolled around literally anyone who had even the slightest interest in batman as a character wanted to see this film. so, the audience on opening night at a suburban multiplex was incredibly varied as were the expectations of the filmgoers: you had clueless boomers who thought they were in for something like the adam west batman, young gen-xers like me and my friends who had seen the old batman tv show in reruns as kids but were also aware of the new “grim and gritty” batman, and true “comic book man” hoping for a shot by shot recreation of frank miller. bear in mind this was a time in which you actually had to physically wait in line at the theater to buy a ticket, in which there was no such thing as assigned seating at a movie etc. so there was a lot of intermingling of different groups, jockeying for seats etc. but nearly everybody was pumped. this was probably the most hyped blockbuster audience i’ve ever been in, a distant second would be phantom menace 9 years later.

this happened more or less in 2001. bush’s justice dept chose to take walmart, best buy and targets’ critique of map and mortally wounded music retail. most people don’t know this but music stores don’t pay for their own ads. labels do. labels used to have map (minimum advertised sale pricing) which said we will advertise our music thru your store and you generally sale price the item. but you can’t sale price it below cost as that does nothing but sour the value of recorded music. the big box retailers, like you said, wanted to sell these things at or below cost as loss leaders and argued that the labels saying you couldn’t price below a certain level was price fixing. 

this was total bullshit. nothing prevented the big boxes from pricing below cost but the labels’ position was we aren’t going to buy the advertising for you to do it (anyone remember the best buy sunday paper circulars?). the bush justice dept ruled that not only did the big boxes have the right to do this but that the record labels had to (as in it would be illegal for them not to) keep their relative media budgets proportionally the same. so if universal spent 30% of their advertising budget thru best buy before map ruling they still needed to give 30% of their budget to best buy after. basically it was mandated to the labels that they would pay for their own demise. at or below cost music exploded. best buy and target used it as leverage to sell more dish washers and laundry detergent but indy stores couldn’t afford to sell things for or below cost b/c no one comes to them for a dishwasher. half of the indy stores were gone in a few years. every national media outlet was screaming at the public that music should cost very little.
